attributes.title: Barriers to cardiac rehabilitation in ethnic minority groups: a scoping review protocol (Registration)
attributes.description: Scoping review aimed to identify barriers associated with cardiac rehabilitation referral, enrollment, and completion of cardiovascular disease patients from ethnic minorities.

summary.value: Cardiac rehabilitation (CR) is a well-established model able to promote positive effects in patients with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). Although the positive effects, studies indicate lower CR referral and participation among patients from ethnic minority, which contribute for increasing mortality on this population.10 It makes important to identify barriers associated with CR referral, enrollment, and completion of patients from ethnic minorities to enable the development of strategies to overcome these barriers and eliminate inequities in CR access and use by these groups. In this context, a scoping review will be conducted in order to systematically map the research done in this area, as well as to identify any existing gaps in knowledge. The aim of this scoping review is to identify barriers associated with CR referral, enrollment, and completion of CVD patients from ethnic minorities.

registration_responses.summary: Cardiac rehabilitation (CR) is a well-established model able to promote positive effects in patients with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). Although the positive effects, studies indicate lower CR referral and participation among patients from ethnic minority, which contribute for increasing mortality on this population.10 It makes important to identify barriers associated with CR referral, enrollment, and completion of patients from ethnic minorities to enable the development of strategies to overcome these barriers and eliminate inequities in CR access and use by these groups. In this context, a scoping review will be conducted in order to systematically map the research done in this area, as well as to identify any existing gaps in knowledge. The aim of this scoping review is to identify barriers associated with CR referral, enrollment, and completion of CVD patients from ethnic minorities.

attributes.title: A model to predict level of adherence to prehabilitation in older adults with frailty having cancer surgery
attributes.description:
BACKGROUND: Frailty is a well-established predictor of adverse postoperative outcomes in older surgical patients and is especially common in older people having cancer surgery. Early evidence suggests exercise could improve postoperative outcomes for people with frailty, however little is known about the factors that influence older people’s adherence in exercise before surgery (prehabilitation) programs.

OBJECTIVE: Our objective is to identify predictors of prehabilitation adherence in older adults living with frailty before cancer surgery.

METHODS: This will be a nested prospective cohort of older adults with frailty having cancer surgery who participated in a randomized controlled trial of home-based prehabilitation vs. standard care to improve postoperative functional performance. It is anticipated that 102 participants from the intervention arm will be included in this study’s nested cohort.

We will construct a multivariable ordinary least squares linear regression model using pre-specified, prospectively collected covariates to predict adherence (% prescribed exercise sessions attempted). Our covariates (collected at baseline) have been selected a priori based on clinical expertise and literature review; they will include age, sex, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), disability, frailty score, previous physical activity, depression, and neoadjuvant therapy. If assumptions of normality are met, our dependent variable will be % adherence; otherwise a log transformation will be applied. All continuous variables will be standardized and assessed for best fit using fractional polynomials. Collinearity will be considered using variance inflation factor and addressed with penalisation. Missing data will be handled using multiple imputation. Bootstrapping will be used to internally validate the model. 

EXPECTED RESULTS: This model will help us to understand the proportion of variance in prehabilitation adherence that is explained by baseline participant characteristics. This will allow for identification of people at risk of low adherence to inform resource targeting and personalization of prehabilitation support systems.

summary.value: This is a registration of plans for the development and validation of a prediction model. The attached file contains the protocol.

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of plans for the development and validation of a prediction model. The attached file contains the protocol.

attributes.title: Evaluating the utility of antibiotic prophylaxis prior to ESWL in patients with sterile urine: a systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Antibiotic prophylaxis (AP) when performing extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) has been a matter of debate for many years. Currently, urological associations around the world suggest that there is no need for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing ESWL with sterile urine. However, hese statements are based on scarce or insufficient data with conflicting results between the reports, It is against this background that our systematic review and meta-analysis aims to address the effect of AP on asymptomatic bacteriuria (AB) and clinical urinary tract infection in patients with preoperative sterile urine and identify potential risk groups .The information produced will prove valuable for everyday urological practice.

q1.value: Dimitrios Memmos, Ioannis Mykoniatis, Petros Sountoulides, Anastasios Anastasiadis, Dimitrios Hatzichristou

q2.value: Currently bibiliography provides information that antibiotic prophylaxis before ESWL decreases the risk of positive urine culture, trial-defined urinary tract infection and fever but in a non-significant way. By evaluating its effect using these outcome measures the interpretation of the results falls to the reader of the publications. Since the current subject has been under debate for many years there is a need for an analysis that has clinicaly-oriented outcomes and provides information that is useful for everyday practice and demostrates as clear as possible the benefits/harms of this intervention

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review and meta-analysis that will be performed with a random-effects model.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
A systematic search will be performed in accordance with the PRISMA guidelines through PubMed, Cochrane Registry, Scopus and Web of Science, as well as grey literature (abstracts and proceedings from conferences and relevant websites).
The inclusion criteria are: i) RCTs performed in humans that compared any form of antibiotic prophylaxis using any route of administration with either placebo or no treatment prior to ESWL. ii) studies including populations with negative urine culture before the procedure and iii) studies published in any language up until the day the search will be conducted.
The exclusion criteria are: i) single arm or comparative studies reporting quantitative data on clinical outcomes of interest ii) case series/case reports; iii) animal or cadaveric studies; iv) secondary research studies (e.g. systematic reviews, meta-analyses, letters to the editor or commentaries) and v) when duplicates are identified, the most recent study will be included.

Asymptomatic bacteriuria (positive urine culture with absence of symptoms indicating f urinary tract infection)
Clinical urinary tract infection( positive urine culture with symptoms indicating of a UTI that needs treatment with antibiotics) (fever may or may not be present)

Pooled analysis will be conducted to calculate the risk ratios (RR) for the evaluation of two clinical outcomes: asymptomatic bacteriuria and clinical urinary tract infection (positive urine culture with urinary tract symptoms indicating of UTI with/without fever). Statistical heterogeneity among included studies and overall analyses were assessed via the use of Mantel–Haenszel Chi-squared based test and I2 parameter.
Data from the included studies will be used to identify potential subgroup analyses that may help identify risk groups that may benefit from AP before ESWL

q20.value: Funnel plot will performed and visually inspected to evaluate publication bias

attributes.title: RT-PCR versus computed tomography - which method has the highest detection rate for COVID-19 in the early stages?
attributes.description:
Objective: 
To determine early detection rate between real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for COVID-19 and computed tomography (CT).
To determine which of the diagnostic techniques has the best detection rate for the early diagnosis of COVID-19.
To determine which method is more sensible for early case detection. 
Methods: rapid systematic review. 
Inclusion criteria: Comparative studies of the detection rate in patients who underwent both CT and RT-PCR for the diagnosis of COVID-19 in the first 7 days of evolution will be included, regardless of the severity of the disease.
We will not place restrictions on patient age or origin or the language or publication status of the study.

Research methods to identify studies: The research will be conducted at the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, LILACS, Tripdatabase and CINAHL until April 18, 2020, and through manual search in relevant journals. The Mesh terms were "Covid-19", "Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction", "Polymerase Chain Reaction", Tomography, X-Ray Computed.
Two independent evaluators will select the studies and a third evaluator will be consulted in case of disagreements. The RTI ITEM Bank tool will be used to analyze the methodological quality.
The data for each study will be summarized in "forests plots", indicating the best diagnostic method with the application of the value of its detection rate, with a 95% confidence interval, and the numbers used to generate it, using software´s automatic function. All analyzes and diagrams will be performed using RevMan 5 and MetaDiSc 1.4.

q1.value: Márcio Luis Duarte, Lucas Ribeiro dos Santos, Andrea Carla de Souza Contenças, Wagner Iared, Maria Stella Peccin

q2.value:
CT Scan has a higher detection rate than RT-PCR.
CT Scan has a detection rate similar to RT-PCR.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: Systematic review that will evaluate the detection rate of RT-PCR and CR Scan for COVID-19 following the Cochrane Diagnostic Reviewer's Handbook. Ir will include comparative studies of the detection rate in patients who underwent both CT and RT-PCR for the diagnosis of COVID-19 in the first 7 days of evolution will be included, regardless of the severity of the disease.

data.name: RT-PCR versus CT for early diagnosis of COVID-19.docx

extra.selectedFileName: RT-PCR versus CT for early diagnosis of COVID-19.docx

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Methods

1. Inclusion criteria
Comparative studies of the detection rate in patients who underwent both CT and RT-PCR for the diagnosis of COVID-19 in the first 7 days of evolution will be included, regardless of the severity of the disease.

We will not place restrictions on patient age or origin or the language or publication status of the study.

2. Research methods to identify studies
Electronic searches.
The research will be conducted at the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, LILACS, Tripdatabase and CINAHL until April 18, 2020 (search strategies available in Appendix 1), and through manual search in relevant journals.


3. Data collection and analysis
We will follow the existing guideline in the Cochrane Diagnostic Reviewer's Handbook (http://srdta.cochrane.org/en/authors.html).

4. Selection of studies
Publications potentially eligible for inclusion based on the abstract will be analyzed independently by two authors. To be eligible, each publication will be evaluated to determine whether participants meet the inclusion criteria detailed above. Abstracts will be included if sufficient data for analysis is provided. Any disagreement will be resolved by consensus by a third author.

5. Data extraction and management
Two authors will independently complete a data extraction form in all included studies.

The following data will be extracted:
1. General information: title, journal, year, publication status, and study design.
2. Sample size: number of participants who meet the criteria and the total number selected.
3. Basic characteristics: diagnosis, age, and sex.
4. Diagnostic tests with defined cut-offs
5. Clinical reference for the standard test.
6. The number of true positives (TP), true negative (TN), false positive (FP), false negative (FN) and analysis of the ROC curve (Receiver operating characteristic). These data will be extracted for each cut point presented and for the two target conditions. Also, the area under the ROC curve will be analyzed.

The correspondence authors of the studies will be contacted in the case of missing data.

6. Methodological quality assessment
Eligible studies will be assessed using the RTI ITEM BANK tool. The tool is based on instruments that cover a wide range of methodological issues in diagnostic test studies, presenting 29 questions for analyzing the quality of the study.

Evaluation of the quality of the studies will be carried out independently by two authors. Any disagreement will be resolved by consensus by a third author.

q11.value: It´s a systematic review, so we will sum up the data of the studies that will be in accordance with our inclusion and quality criteria to carry out the analysis in the "forests plots" graphs

question.value: We will analyse studies that evaluate RT-PCR and CT Scan for the diagnosis of COVID-19 in the first week of the symptoms.
Odds ratio and chi-squared test using MetaDisc 1.4 and RevMan 5.

q21.value: The correspondence authors of the studies will be contacted in the case of missing data.

attributes.title: Palliative Care in Heart Failure: a systematic review of registered clinical trials
attributes.description:
**Type of project:** Systematic review

**Principal Investigator and guarantor:** Daniel Caldeira, MD, PhD.

**Institution:** Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de Lisboa, Portugal.

Departments: CCUL - Centro Cardiovascular da Universidade de Lisboa; Laboratory of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, Faculdade de Medicina, Universidade de Lisboa, Portugal. 

*Project aimed to be the Master Thesis of Catarina Manuel Borges E Gonçalves Da Silva (Medicine Student)*

Funding: None.


----------

AIM: to summarize and appraise the available evidence on palliative care interventions and outcomes studied in registered clinical trials.

**PICOS data:**

Patients: Patients Heart failure
Intervention: Palliative Care: Palliative care is defined as an intervention whose main goal is the relief of suffering by means of pain management and physical, psychological and spiritual interventions, and improvement of the quality of life through the interdisciplinary care of patients and families facing an advance stage of a chronic illness. As consequence the studies whose intervention is referred as hospice care, comfort care, supportive care, advanced care, pain and palliative care service, will also be included.
Comparator/Control: N/A
Outcome: Mortality N/A
Study design: Controlled studies (published or unpublished)

----------

**Brief Methodological and Statistical Analysis Plan:**

Databases for Search: clinicaltrials.gov; WHO ICTRP; clinicaltrialsregister.eu; ISRCTN registry
Meta-analysis planned: No
Risk of Bias evaluation: No
Pooled data confidence evaluation: N/A

----------
**Milestones:**
Project Initiation: August 2018
Search Date: October 2018
Expected Project end: April/May 2020

attributes.title: Is workaholism realted with anxiety?
attributes.description:
AUTHORS
Kristian Cannavò, Pietro Cordiano, Maddalena Polato, Jacopo Tajana, Pietro Conti.

Previous researches have shown a link between high levels of workaholism and anxiety.
Due to the incompleteness of collected data on the topic, we design research for the purpose of deepening the knowledge about the over-mentioned connection.

Although it is not real and official research but just a project for a statistic class we decided to register the project since we are going to collect and analyze data in order to give more reliability to our research.

q2.value:
1 - Workaholism is positively correlated with trait anxiety.
   -  Workaholism is positively correlated with state anxiety.

2 Which one between state anxiety and trait anxiety has a greater impact on workaholism

3 During COVID-19 epidemy, workers who work at home will show lowers levels of state anxiety compared those who work  at the workplace

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Previous researches (Clark et alt 2014) have shown a link between high levels of workaholism and anxiety.
Due to the incompleteness of collected data on the topic, we design research for the purpose of deepening the knowledge about the over-mentioned connection.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Through two questionnaires State-Trait Anxiety Inventory Forma Y e il Dutch Work Addiction Scale. We are going to collect data on a sample taken within Italian workers.
Due to the peculiar situation (COVID-19 epidemy), we are going to distribute the mentioned questionnaire using an online version created with google docs.
we will exclude all participants that will not complete the 50 percent of the whole questionaire.

1° Hypothesis.
 Although we will not manipulate any variables because of our project it's about to distribute questionnaires and collecting data. One variable can be identified in the level of workaholism the other in the level of trait anxiety and another in-state anxiety.

2° Hypothesis State anxiety and trait anxiety

3° Hypothesis.
 One variable is the typology of work the employers are adopting, work at home/work at the workplace / not working.

-Trait Anxiety 
-State Anxiety
-Workaholism
-Method of work currently adopted

We are going to export data from Google modules to Excel, where the raw scores of the STAI-Y and DUWAS will be calculated. 
Firstly we'll calculate the Pearson correlation coefficient between Duwas and STAY (Hp1).
Then we will calculate which one of the two anxieties has a greater impact (Hp2) correlation with R. 
Then we'll Compare state anxiety for those who work at the workplace and for those who work at home (Hp2) with a t-test.

q20.value: All incomplete questionnaire will be excluded.

registration_responses.q2:
1 - Workaholism is positively correlated with trait anxiety.
   -  Workaholism is positively correlated with state anxiety.

2 Which one between state anxiety and trait anxiety has a greater impact on workaholism

3 During COVID-19 epidemy, workers who work at home will show lowers levels of state anxiety compared those who work  at the workplace
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Are autistic adults impaired on an Emotional Switching Task compared to typically developed control?
attributes.description: Despite every day life impairments in cognitive flexibility are frequently reported in autism, these impairments are more inconsistent in laboratory experiments (Teunisse et al., 2012). Geurts et al. (2009) posit that mixed result could emerge from a lack of ecological validity of laboratory tasks, due to the predictable nature of the stimuli as well as their simple content. Hence, we propose a new flexibility task, including unpredictable changes and complex emotional content, in order to test flexibility impairments in autistic participants as compared to a control group. We hypothesize that autistic participants will be more impaired than typically developing participants on the task.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Are autistic adults more impaired on an Emotional Switching Task compared to typically developed control?

other.value:
TST Task:
The TST task can’t be directly compared to the EST task because of the differences between tasks, involving different cognitive function. Specifically, working memory, which is usually impaired in autism (Habib et al., 2019), is strongly involved in the TST. Nevertheless, we will compare our two groups on these tasks. The switch cost of the task will result in a main effect of shift, that will manifest by lesser CR and larger RT in the shift than in the non-shift condition. We also expect a group effect: we expect a lesser CR and a larger RT in ASD. However, ss the switch in the TST task is explicitly cued and predictable, we do not expect any interaction between the Shift conditions and the Group. We will conduct a mixed-model analyses using the lme4 package in R to compare CR and RT for the Shift effect (shift and non-shift) and the Groups (ASD and TD).

Correlation between EST and TST:
For the control group, we predict a positive correlation between reaction time in TST and reaction time in EST when shifting. That is, the better participants' performance in the TST switch condition is, the better participants performed on the EST during the switch condition. On the contrary, we do not expect a significant correlation between the reaction time on the TST and on the EST in the ASD group. Correlation analysis will be conducted using the ggpubr package in R.

All procedures that will be performed in this study involving human participants are in accordance with the Code of Ethics of the World Medical Association (Declaration of Helsinki) and approved by the local ethics committee (CER-Grenoble Alps, COMUE University Grenoble Alpes, IRB00010290).

See the complete preregistration document in the project for more details

sample.value:
As we are working with a new type of flexibility task, we cannot perform a power analysis. We plan to recruit one hundred participants in the autistic group and one hundred participants in the typically developed (TD) control group. 
Autistic participants will be recruited with the help of expertise centers dedicated to autism diagnosis, psychologists specialized in support for autistic person or associations for the autism community. TD control participants will be recruited by advertisement or social networks.
All participants will have to be French speaking, aged from 18 to 45, and participation is only possible subsequent to providing informed consent. Autistic participants need to have a clinical diagnosis by a multidisciplinary team from an Expertise Center, a regional center, or trained psychologists and psychiatrists.
Participants are not allowed to participate to the study if they cannot use a computer with a real keyboard, if they are on curatorship or guardianship, if they have non corrected visual impairments, if they have neurological condition, psychiatric condition or treatment which could impair performances to the task or in case of drugs or alcohol consumption before the task.

analyses.value:
Hypotheses on the EST: 
We expect that the switch cost of the task will result in a main effect of shift, that will manifest by fewer CR and longer RTs in the shift than in the non-shift condition. We also expect that the complex socio-emotional nature of the stimuli will be more challenging for autistic participant compared to control. This will lead to a lesser CR and a longer RT for the ASD group compared to the control group. We also expect two interaction effects. As the shift is not cued and requires an autonomous exploration of a complex social scene, we expect a smaller difference in RT between shift and non-shift condition in ASD compared to TD control. Moreover, we expect that the cognitive inflexibility of autistic participants will conduct to more errors for ASD in the shift condition, resulting in a larger difference in CR between shift and non-shift condition in ASD compared to TD control.
We will conduct mixed-model analyses using the lme4 package in R to compare CR and RT for the Shift conditions (shift and non-shift) and the Groups (ASD and TD).

Supplementary analysis:
EST Task:
1.	The effect of the type of emotional shift
Positive emotional stimuli usually elicited faster RT than negative one (Leppänen et al., 2003), particularly in young persons while it could sometimes reverse with aging (Kauschke et al., 2019). The type of emotional shift will be added in our model and we expect an interaction between the shift effect and the emotional type. More specifically, we expect a larger switch cost (difference between switching and non-switching condition) when shifting from positive to negative (vs positive to positive) compared to shifting from negative to positive (vs negative to negative). 
2.	The effect of gender
Gender differences in autism are more and more reported. Particularly, autistic females seem to have enhanced attention to faces as compared to autistic males (Harrop et al., 2018). They also have better social camouflaging (Schuck et al., 2019) and flexibility abilities (Bölte et al., 2011). Even if TD females might be faster at categorizing socio-emotional scenes (Vanmarcke & Wagemans, 2015), emotion recognition seems not to differ between autistic males and females on a task without contextual cues (Baron-Cohen et al., 2015). They might even be more impaired in emotion categorization during complex situations (Vanmarcke et al., 2016). Hence, we also plan to perform analysis with gender as a between subject factor.
3.	Education
We will control the influence of the education al level, included it as a covariable in the model.
4.	Variability in autistic participants:
As autism is a large spectrum, we might have high variability in the results of autistic participants. In this case, we plan to perform analysis ranking the ASD group on their reaction time, similarly to De Vries and Geurts (2012).

outliers.value:
We plan to exclude participants if:
-	They have low performances in the Simple Emotion Condition on the EST (< 75% correct).
-	Trials with RT < 300 ms (in the EST and in the TST) 
-	Participants with high scores on the PANAS (positive affects < 18 and negative affects > 29; Crawford & Henry, 2004).
-	TD participants with an AQ score > 32.

dependent.value: For each trial in each flexibility task (EST and TST), we will collect if the answer is correct or not and then compute the correct response rate (CR). We will also collect the response time. CR and response time for correct responses (RT) will be the dependent variables.

conditions.value:
Autistic participants will be compared to control participants. For each flexibility task (EST and TST), there will be two conditions, described below:  the shifting condition and the non-shifting condition.

Procedure and material
The experiment will be performed online on the Psytoolkit platform (Stoet, 2010, 2016). Using online experiment is particularly relevant with autistic participants regarding their difficulties with changes and with social communication. Autistic persons usually feel more comfortable with online communication, as it allows more control, it reduces stress related to social interactions and it ensure to protect their privacy (Benford & Standen, 2009; Gillespie-Lynch et al., 2014). Therefore online experiment could facilitate optimal performances. The Psytoolkit platform allow reliable data collection for correct response rate and response time (Kim et al., 2019). The experiment will include 5 parts. Part 2 and 3 will be counterbalanced. Before the first part, the participant will be informed about the experiment and will have to give its informed consent. 

Part 1: Demographical data
During this first part, we will collect demographical data. All participants will have to report their age, sex, education level, and handedness. They will have to report if they have a normal or corrected to normal visual acuity. Participants will also have to report if they have another psychiatric or neurological diagnosis (with a general YES/NO answer), if they have a developmental diagnosis (e.g., dyslexia, ADHD) except autism, and if they have a pharmacological treatment that might impair their cognitive functions. 
Then, participants will also have to self-report if they have an autism diagnosis, and if yes, which kind of autism diagnosis. We will ensure that they received a clinical diagnosis by asking them which type of professional has delivered their diagnosis.

Part 2: The Emotional Shifting task (Biro et al., in prep)
During this second part, participants will have to perform an 8 minutes Emotional Shifting Task (EST), developed by (Biro et al., in prep). Contrary to previous emotional flexibility tasks, where the participant had to switch between an emotional task and another type of task, the switch in the EST will remain in the emotional domain and emotional faces will include their context, which is more ecological. During this task, the participant will have to recognize the valence of an emotion on a truncated picture (i.e., without context), in the Simple Emotion condition. This will enable us to evaluate the ability of the participant to recognize a simple emotion without context. Then, the same image will appear untruncated (i.e., with its context) and again, the participant will have to recognize the valence of the emotion. This will be the Complex Emotion condition. During the non-shifting condition (which could be either from positive to positive or negative to negative), the context will be congruent with the emotion that appears at the first sight during the Simple Emotion Condition. During the shifting condition (which could be either positive to negative or negative to positive), it will be incongruent. Hence, the participant will have to decide to change his first judgment or not, by picking up cues in the context, which have the predictive value to perform the task. Cueing is not explicit here. Moreover, shifting and non-shifting conditions are randomly mixed (unpredictable). To give his answer, the participant will have to press the keyboard (B or V key) with his index (the right index for right handed and left index for left handed). The side of emotion will be counterbalanced (B for positive and V for negative for half of the participants and the contrary for the other half).

Part 3: The Task Switching Task (Rogers & Monsell, 1995).
The participant will then perform a cognitive flexibility task lasting 8 minutes: the Task Switching Task (TST). During this task, a square will appear on the screen, which will be divided into four cells. A letter and a number will appear side by side, on the top left cell, then on the top right cell, then on the bottom right cell and finally on the bottom left cell, and so on and so forth. When the stimulus will appear on the top cells, the participant will have to perform the letter task, that is, press V if the letter is a consonant and press B if the letter is a vowel. When the stimulus will appear in the bottom cells, the participant will have to perform the number task, that is press V if the number is odd and press B if the number is even. As the task is difficult, and implies to be memorized, the participant will be first trained only on the letter task, then the participant will be trained only on the number task, and finally, he will perform mixed tasks. When tasks will be mixed, the order will always be the same (previously described). Hence, the participant will know when the switch between task will appear (predictable) and he will also know exactly what to do as the cue for the switch is explicit.

Part 4: Autism Spectrum Quotient (AS - Baron-Cohen et al., 2001)
This is a 10 minutes questionnaire aiming at evaluating autistic traits in the participant. A score above 32 is usually associated to high autistic traits.

Part 5: Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS - Watson et al., 1988)
This is a 5 minutes questionnaire that aims to detect anxious and depressive states. Scores above the 5th percentile (Positive affects < 18; Negative affects > 29) are correlated with depressive and/or anxious states (Crawford & Henry, 2004).

hypothesis.value:
Autism Spectrum Disorders  are characterized by socio-communicative impairments associated with specific interests, repetitive behaviors as well as sensory specificities (American Psychiatric Association et al., 2015). Repetitive behaviors and the difficulty for autistic people to change their plans and routines is an expression of their cognitive inflexibility. Cognitive flexibility is the ability to switch from one task to another, or to change strategy or perspective according to the situation. Thus, it is an essential adaptive skill, which implies to be attentive to relevant cues (which have a predictive value for the switch) and also to disengage attention to irrelevant ones. Real-life cognitive flexibility impairments are usually well reported by using the shift sub-scale of the BRIEF questionnaire (Gioia et al., 2000; Roth et al., 2005), which discriminates autistic adults from typically developing (TD) controls (Leung & Zakzanis, 2014). However, laboratory results on flexibility are quite inconsistent and poorly differentiate autistic participants from TD controls (Leung & Zakzanis, 2014). De Vries and Geurts (2012) suggest that mixed results could be related to a lack of ecological validity of most of these tests. Everyday life situations usually require the processing of complex stimuli and adaptation to unpredictable changes. De Vries and Geurts (2012) created a flexibility task with unpredictable changes and involving human emotional faces, which are more ecological stimuli. Thus, the task explored the interplay between socio-emotional information processing and cognitive flexibility in autism, studying the interactive effect of the two main symptoms of autism, usually studied separately. In their task, participants were seeing faces and had to report either the gender or the emotion of the face, according to a cue appearing just above the face. Contrary to their prediction, authors found no overall difference in performances between autistic children and TD controls. They suggested that the lack of significant results could emerge from the predictable nature of their task as the switch, despite being unannounced, was guided by explicit rules (i.e., the cue indicating the switch). They also suggested that the emotional content was to simple (only two basics emotions) and could therefore reduce the ecological validity of the task. In real-life, rules are implicit, usually requiring the processing of multiple cues. Hence, flexibility impairments in autism would mainly appear during complex tasks, for instance, when the task require an autonomous exploration of the relevant cues to achieve the task. It might explain why performances at the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST), in which the rule has to be guessed by the participant, are usually impaired in autism (Landry & Al-Taie, 2016), despite other flexibility tasks often fail to differentiate autistic participants from TD controls. In WCST, studies usually show more perseverative errors in autism compared to TD controls (Landry & Al-Taie, 2016). Latinus et al. (2019) also explored the interplay between socio-emotional information processing and cognitive flexibility, using an emotional WCST. Participants have to abstract the rule to pair the central face with a surrounding one, either by the identity, by the emotion, or by the frame color. Contrary to Landry and Al-Taie (2016), they found no group difference for perseverative and non-perseverative errors and attribute this result to the task explicitness. However, they found that autistic participants committed more errors than control participants when they have to find the emotion rule. This result can reveal more difficulties for autistic participants to switch toward emotional processing, but has not been found in the study of De Vries and Geurts (2012). 
Van de Cruys et al. (2014) hypothesize that flexibility impairments in autism could be explained by a more general framework, encompassing the different autism symptoms, relying on predictive coding frameworks. They suggest that autism characteristics can be explained by high and inflexible precision of prediction errors. Prediction errors is the difference between the sensory input and predictions (or priors, which are abstracted from past experiences). The weight allowed to prediction errors should be adapted according to meta-learning (i.e., learning of the relevant characteristics for realizing the task). High precision to prediction error means that each error is seen as “important”, thus preventing from meta-learning. Consequently, it would create a prolonged processing of stimuli, particularly if they are unpredicted, and deficit in disengaging (Van de Cruys et al., 2014) that can result in perseveration, and might thus explain flexibility impairments. This would also explain several social difficulties experienced by autistic persons, as emotional faces and social situations are particularly complex, changing, and context-bound. Meta-learning of which cues are informative is thus very challenging in these situations.
The objective of our study is to examine the effect of unpredictability and non-cued switches of a complex socio-emotional environment on flexibility of autistic participants compared to a TD control group. To this end, we employed the novel Emotional Shifting Task (EST, Biro et al., in prep) to assess emotional flexibility.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Are autistic adults more impaired on an Emotional Switching Task compared to typically developed control?
registration_responses.other:
TST Task:
The TST task can’t be directly compared to the EST task because of the differences between tasks, involving different cognitive function. Specifically, working memory, which is usually impaired in autism (Habib et al., 2019), is strongly involved in the TST. Nevertheless, we will compare our two groups on these tasks. The switch cost of the task will result in a main effect of shift, that will manifest by lesser CR and larger RT in the shift than in the non-shift condition. We also expect a group effect: we expect a lesser CR and a larger RT in ASD. However, ss the switch in the TST task is explicitly cued and predictable, we do not expect any interaction between the Shift conditions and the Group. We will conduct a mixed-model analyses using the lme4 package in R to compare CR and RT for the Shift effect (shift and non-shift) and the Groups (ASD and TD).

Correlation between EST and TST:
For the control group, we predict a positive correlation between reaction time in TST and reaction time in EST when shifting. That is, the better participants' performance in the TST switch condition is, the better participants performed on the EST during the switch condition. On the contrary, we do not expect a significant correlation between the reaction time on the TST and on the EST in the ASD group. Correlation analysis will be conducted using the ggpubr package in R.

All procedures that will be performed in this study involving human participants are in accordance with the Code of Ethics of the World Medical Association (Declaration of Helsinki) and approved by the local ethics committee (CER-Grenoble Alps, COMUE University Grenoble Alpes, IRB00010290).

See the complete preregistration document in the project for more details

As we are working with a new type of flexibility task, we cannot perform a power analysis. We plan to recruit one hundred participants in the autistic group and one hundred participants in the typically developed (TD) control group. 
Autistic participants will be recruited with the help of expertise centers dedicated to autism diagnosis, psychologists specialized in support for autistic person or associations for the autism community. TD control participants will be recruited by advertisement or social networks.
All participants will have to be French speaking, aged from 18 to 45, and participation is only possible subsequent to providing informed consent. Autistic participants need to have a clinical diagnosis by a multidisciplinary team from an Expertise Center, a regional center, or trained psychologists and psychiatrists.
Participants are not allowed to participate to the study if they cannot use a computer with a real keyboard, if they are on curatorship or guardianship, if they have non corrected visual impairments, if they have neurological condition, psychiatric condition or treatment which could impair performances to the task or in case of drugs or alcohol consumption before the task.

Autistic participants will be compared to control participants. For each flexibility task (EST and TST), there will be two conditions, described below:  the shifting condition and the non-shifting condition.

Procedure and material

Using online experiment is particularly relevant with autistic participants regarding their difficulties with changes and with social communication. Autistic persons usually feel more comfortable with online communication, as it allows more control, it reduces stress related to social interactions and it ensure to protect their privacy (Benford & Standen, 2009; Gillespie-Lynch et al., 2014). Therefore online experiment could facilitate optimal performances. The Psytoolkit platform allow reliable data collection for correct response rate and response time (Kim et al., 2019). The experiment will include 5 parts. Part 2 and 3 will be counterbalanced. Before the first part, the participant will be informed about the experiment and will have to give its informed consent.

The participant will then perform a cognitive flexibility task lasting 8 minutes: the Task Switching Task (TST). Part 4: Autism Spectrum Quotient (AS - Baron-Cohen et al., 2001)
This is a 10 minutes questionnaire aiming at evaluating autistic traits in the participant. A score above 32 is usually associated to high autistic traits.

This is a 5 minutes questionnaire that aims to detect anxious and depressive states. Scores above the 5th percentile (Positive affects < 18; Negative affects > 29) are correlated with depressive and/or anxious states (Crawford & Henry, 2004).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Autism Spectrum Disorders  are characterized by socio-communicative impairments associated with specific interests, repetitive behaviors as well as sensory specificities (American Psychiatric Association et al., 2015). Repetitive behaviors and the difficulty for autistic people to change their plans and routines is an expression of their cognitive inflexibility. Cognitive flexibility is the ability to switch from one task to another, or to change strategy or perspective according to the situation. Thus, it is an essential adaptive skill, which implies to be attentive to relevant cues (which have a predictive value for the switch) and also to disengage attention to irrelevant ones. Real-life cognitive flexibility impairments are usually well reported by using the shift sub-scale of the BRIEF questionnaire (Gioia et al., 2000; Roth et al., 2005), which discriminates autistic adults from typically developing (TD) controls (Leung & Zakzanis, 2014). However, laboratory results on flexibility are quite inconsistent and poorly differentiate autistic participants from TD controls (Leung & Zakzanis, 2014). The objective of our study is to examine the effect of unpredictability and non-cued switches of a complex socio-emotional environment on flexibility of autistic participants compared to a TD control group. To this end, we employed the novel Emotional Shifting Task (EST, Biro et al., in prep) to assess emotional flexibility.
